bibl.title: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, May 19, 1920

div1.p: Rose expresses confidence in Carter's abilities to control the spread of yellow fever, but he is concerned about Carter's health.

div1.head: Letter from Wickliffe Rose to Henry Rose Carter, May 19, 1920
div1.opener:

DIRECTOR OF
SURVEYS AND EXHIBITS
MEMBERS
-----
GEORGE E. VINCENT
CHAIRMAN
HERMANN M. BIGGS
WALLACE BUTTRICK
SIMON FLEXNER
FREDERICK T. GATES
WILLIAM C. GORGAS
STARR J. MURPHY
JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, JR.
WICKLIFFE ROSE
WILLIAM T. SEDGWICK
VICTOR C. VAUGHAN
WILLIAM H. WELCH
------
EDWIN R. EMBREE
SECRETARY
THE ROCKEFELLER FOUNDATION
INTERNATIONAL HEALTH BOARD
61 BROADWAY, NEW YORK
May 19, 1920.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
Thank you very much for the reprint of your arti-
cle on the “Mechanism of the Spontaneous Elimination of
Yellow Fever from Endemic Centers”. I shall read this with
the keenest interest. No other man is so well qualified to
speak on this subject as you.

It was a great pleasure to see you the other day.
I know how your interest in yellow fever will be driving you
to return to Peru. So long as that situation is in your
hands we have no anxiety. On the other hand, we are inter-
ested in your personal welfare. Dr. Heiser and I talked
this over after you went away. We feel very strongly that
you ought to look after yourself and that you should not re-
turn to Peru unless you feel that you are thoroughly justi-
fied by your physical condition in doing so. You have done
enough good work in the world to justify your taking the
very best care of yourself now.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Wickliffe Rose. Dr. H. R. Carter,
U. S. Marine Hospital,
Baltimore, Maryland.
